And it's not always about something being kind of, is this super compelling, and does it check out with fact checks, but more about what are our preexisting beliefs. Many more people will see the incendiary false version of a story than the fact checked correct version that goes out later. So there's a very kind of unfortunate asymmetry there about who sees false information. This is YouTube kind of shoving them in the faces of people that were not even looking for them. And just if you're not familiar, Alex Jones is the most prolific conspiracy theorist of the 21st century, according to the Southern Poverty Law Center. But one of his conspiracy theories was to say that the Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting did not take place. And his kind of videos and theory around this led to this years-long harassment case against many of the parents whose children were murdered. And so their parents whose children were murdered, people are claiming the shooting didn't take place. And they've had to move houses multiple times to try to evade harassment. So it's just really terrible and terrible that YouTube would, again, show these videos 15 billion times to people that were not looking for them. And I covered a lot of the kind of history around YouTube and what research has been done. And my post was this Google executive deeply misinformed relying in the New York Times. And that covers kind of a very misleading interview that a YouTube executive recently had, as well as I go into a lot of the history and the research. This is a great graph that Guillaume Cheslot put together. And so he has software he's written that basically kind of opens a browser with no history and then follows the chain of recommendations that he gets on YouTube and does this at scale to kind of study it quantitatively. And basically, so this graph, the x-axis is showing the number of channels recommending a video. The y-axis is the views, log of the views per video. And you see we have this extreme outlier of Russia Today's take on the Mueller report. And Russia Today is a Russia state-owned media outlet. And basically, it was being recommended from this huge range of channels across the political spectrum. And so this should be concerning that something is off, that you kind of have this outlier of certain videos being recommended so, so much. And this is something that Russia Today has done very well at, and I think there's kind of reason to believe that they're really studying kind of how to manipulate the algorithm. And then I just think in context, that kind of makes it particularly dark, this pushing, having billions of hours watched per day, above all else. And this, I'm kind of running out of time. I'll just briefly mention this is not disinformation, but YouTube was found to be basically curating videos for pedophiles of kind of what were innocent home videos taken in which children may not be fully clothed. And YouTube was creating these playlists. There was a New York Times investigation where it would even kind of often start with like sexy videos of adult women, and then get younger and younger women, until it's showing people kind of prepubescent children, which is really horrifying. And YouTube told the New York Times reporter that they would not turn off recommendations of videos containing children because it drives too much engagement for them, which I think says a lot about YouTube's priorities. So this is kind of the link is that recommendation systems will really amplify disinformation, or already are amplifying disinformation. And this will just continue to be a problem as we deal with even more. So towards solutions, as I mentioned earlier, these are really tough problems. There was a workshop at ICML on detecting audiovisual fakes. A few years ago, there was a fake news challenge of identifying fake news. And I think that's valuable research. However, because you can, if you have a generator, kind of something generating fake news, and a discriminator that can identify it, you can always use your discriminator to try to make your fakes even more compelling. So this is always going to be an arms race. And so for that reason, I think we need tech and policy to address this. Orin Ecziani, the head of the Allen Institute on AI, wrote a great article in HBR earlier this year, and talks about the issue AI is poised to make high fidelity forgery inexpensive and automated. And he proposes that we need digital signatures for authentication as a way to address this. And this will also involve a huge shift, though, in cultural norms. So it's not just the technology to involve digital signatures, but also to get people not trusting media that doesn't have them, and trusting media that does. So this is a huge task, but I think it's necessary. Zeynep Tefekci wrote something similar in Wired, only she kind of frames this as verified content, but the need for verification so that people can know what's real. And she kind of gives an analogy with, you always hear this as a historical example of when people would hold up a newspaper with the day's date and take a picture to prove that they were still alive. Fidel Castro did this in 2006 after he got out surgery, and there were kind of all these rumors of, is Fidel Castro still alive? So he posed for a picture with today's newspaper, or that date's newspaper. That's something that already with, I think, Photoshop could be faked. And so we'll need kind of the digital analog for that of how we do this. Zeynep wrote, this is an inflection point. We need new methods of authentication that do not yet exist. If you have met me in the last few years, you know I've been begging technologists in the anti-censorship space to work on this, not just circumvention. Then I mentioned, here's the article by Renee DeResta and Mike Godwin in Just Security, and they really think disinformation should be framed as a cybersecurity problem. And so really looking at kind of manipulative and inorganic patterns of how media is being created and post. Renee also wrote a great post in Wired just this month making analogies with spam, and kind of how, you know, spam is now filtered out. We don't even see it in our inboxes unless we want to go into our spam filter, how we need to kind of do something similar with low quality information. And then I guess we're out of time. I just wanted to link to, you can watch this. I'll share the link on C-SPAN. This is a video of Danielle Citrin, a law professor testifying before the Health Intelligence Committee on this fact. And she does a really kind of interesting explanation. She talks about Section 230, which is a 1996 law that grants immunity to tech platforms for kind of anything hosted on their sites. And there have been different proposals about how to change this. I know Guillaume Chazalot has suggested that we need separate laws to deal with recommendation systems. So maybe publishers can still have immunity for what they host, but not what they recommend. And Danielle Citrin has a proposal around Section 230. Yeah, and then I just wanted to link to the malicious use of AI report again as another place kind of outlying steps we need to take. So it's 1 o'clock. We're at time. You can stay if you have questions, but I think this issue of disinformation is a huge one. And you can see just from kind of the range of tech companies that were mentioned in this and the types of technologies being used, that it's very pervasive and I think will be relevant in many, many jobs that you may go on to do. Thank you. And the final exam will be Thursday.
